RT @itshamhocks: Okay everyone. Come with me on the journey of how Boom’s going to lose this one.
(And, you know, if there are girlfriend kisses at the end of it, that’s nice too!)

To be perfectly honest, Quetzal was a villain. There are skeletons in her closet so she’s going to have a lot to face off against. But this isn’t about those fears and regrets anymore. This is about Quetzal showing the world (and herself) that she’s a real hero, that she is good.

SPOILERS AHEAD:

Quetzal’s initial drive was to run away: away from her father and his hopes for her, then away from her life of crime and Curse. Now she’s running towards something: Portia, her girlfriend from another dimension, despite the universe constantly separating them.

We’ll let @Fabby_Garza tell everyone how Quetzal will face off against her past, but before that we just want to say how absolutely proud we are of Quetzal. Quetzal (and Fabby) joined our team just a few months ago but her passion has carried and will carry her far. https://t.co/QylfYphhqe

Aguila’s image of perfection is his child following in his footsteps. But he was wrong. Quetzal is perfect, as she is, no questions asked.

So sure, put her up against an “idealized” version of herself any day. She knows who she is, she doesn’t need to prove it to anyone.

When you’re trans, before you come out, you often feel like you’re competing with the version of yourself that everyone else wants you to be. Quetzal has done that. Her father had an “ideal” version of her that he wanted to see and she fought against that. https://t.co/2vaqDsqwNB

And, after over a hundred issues, Cataclysm Crew is coming to an end. March 30th is the last issue of Cataclysm Crew. We have plans for what's going to replace it, but we do want to give the line a proper send off, which means we're doing a Q&A!

All three of these heroes were villainous at one point: they know how villains think, what drives them. But they each have their own motivations (venting frustration, protecting loved ones, putting on a good show) so they’re ultimately tireless in their pursuit of heroism.

Lastly: AV. Allie’s single motivation is to have fun and be entertaining (“for the readers” whatever that means). If there’s no thrill, she will “find” it (see: make it; i.e. dragging Ben to Hell, forcing LH into a team up). Villain after villain? Sounds like a good time to her!

Next, Quetzal. Quetzal is a hero because she turned over a new leaf, but she’s also driven by her drive to protect her girlfriend. If a horde of villains is the only thing separating her and Portia? No problem. They’ve found their way back to each other through much worse, right?

First up, Velvet. Velvet is a creature driven primarily by rage: rage at its shape, at society, and at individuals. She holds back so SABRE doesn’t keep her imprisoned, but here it can let loose. Give her any villain, every villain, let it go wild, and see how they run.

So she’ll bite back her anger, because anger releases more of the Beast, and she’ll do what needs to be done to save them. Because, at the end of the day, she’s a hero first.

Vote for The Wild Thing, AV, Quetzal, and Velvet in the Moon Harbor bracket next week!

Clara has lived through a long term medical condition, often leaving her defenseless and not in control of her life. She fights to protect those without autonomy now: Hilda, the Greenwing Project kids, etc. She’s not going to let someone hurt a whole city of helpless citizens.

And last but not least, the Wild Thing. Clara’s got the toughest job in this fight. Both she and the Golden Glove have reckless monstrosities living in their mind that want to rush out and wreak havoc. But Clara’s strength in this comes from her compassion. 🖼: @Arellustration https://t.co/hZsF7kPNta

But her power isn’t what will carry her through this challenge. Frankly, she’ll be carried through by her aloofness. She doesn’t get angry, because she claims none of this is real and it’s all just a comic book. Nothing can phase her, so she’ll easily defeat Gorlox with a smile.

Next we have AV. AV/Allie is undeniably the most powerful hero in Moon Harbor: she can bend reality to her very will, jump through time, and conjure necessary tools to her side. (She claims she’s doing this by manipulating the comic pages but we don’t know what that means.)

Quetzal’s temper only rises when her father is involved or if her girlfriend is in danger; Portia just moved safely on to round three and her dad is not in the digitized world, so she can focus on using her strength to force Gorlox back and her flight to evade its attacks.

Next up is Quetzal. Quetzal is one of the newer members of the Moon Harbor team. A recently reformed villain, the blue-winged Quetzal is putting all her energy into being a good person and a good girlfriend. So she’ll do everything she can to protect the city and its people.

On the other hand, we’ve seen her as a skilled fighter. She is scarier than even Gorlox with an adaptive style that lets it entangle and incapacitate foes or outright attack them with jagged spikes to drive them off. She used to have a temper but her teammate Jimmy quelled that.

Velvet is a creature made of a flexible black slime. Its body can be liquid for quick movement or as hard as daggers for offensive and defensive attacks. With her near invulnerability, it can easily make a shield over the city and let Gorlox wear itself out. 🖼: @DragonGirlJosie https://t.co/R9Un9jAMHW

Moon Harbor is produced by @icynewyear, @tphuth94, @elliotylen, and @thecrumpit. If you have questions, DM us here, email us at moonharborheroes@gmail.com, or join our Discord (link in bio). 

And, of course, you can find our issues on your podcatcher of choice!

Moon Harbor Extended, on the other hand, is more a traditional anthology series. The stories on this feed explore different places, different times, and different types of heroes. Cosmic takes our readers to space, The Dishonorables to our villainous past, Hellspawn to Hell, etc.

Moon Harbor Heroes features two primary lines: Faces and Cataclysm Crew. Both have extensive backlogs, but there is a recap in each line about halfway through to help alleviate that. On this feed, there are also holiday issues and special events, which often feature indie games.

There are obviously millions of organizations you can donate to and these are just a few. If you don’t have the financial means to support this #GivingTuesday, then share as much as you can!

The Marsha P. Johnson Institute supports and provides resources for black trans people, including providing fellowship opportunities for artists and community activists. They also host workshops and currently have a COVID recovery fund. Donate at https://t.co/IvbuuhFMrf.

NAACP Legal and Educational Fund does some of the most active advocacy for black Americans, providing legal funds for incarcerated or charged individuals and resources for dismantling white supremacy. They are matching donations made today up to $275,000. https://t.co/NHWDN2XHji

Breath and Shadow (Ability Maine) is a literary journal that works exclusively with and pays writers with disabilities to tell their own stories. Their journals are available online to read now and you can donate at https://t.co/nvRm2z6vrx.

Dungeons and Drama Nerds explores the intersection of theatre and TTRPGs. It focuses on creating a shared dramaturgy through actual play and discussion episodes, ranging from safety mechanics to game design to storytelling, as well as interviews with creatives in both fields!

We’ve already got some cool stuff lined up to highlight other games and game designers in 2021 on both our main and extended feed. But I wanted to shout out these awesome games once more, because each one was unique and spectacular. Check them out and buy one (or all of them)!

The last game we played this year (Storyteller 18-19) was Anyone Can Wear the Mask by @PartyOfOnePod (https://t.co/zZg73NGEDv), which lets you play as a superhero, their villain, and the city they swore to protect. It tells a different type of superhero story and is so adaptable.

Our next Storyteller Issues (15-16) were played using Die Laughing by @NerdBurgerCraig (https://t.co/T0jLPXkEW6), where we played as characters (and producers) of a horror-comedy film. It’s GMless, hilarious, and so much bloody, spooky fun.

We’ve got three more of those set for 2021 (two others with guests and new games and the seventh lifetime, which will bring us full circle with Crossing the Seven Stars), so keep your eyes peeled for those!

- (Storyteller 17) Knowing You, by @justasummerjob (https://t.co/Am5wEc9t2C), examines a relationship from the end back to the start through a series of prompts. It lets you dig into the messiness of a couple’s history in a safe way. It’s heartbreaking but beautiful.

- (Storyteller 14) Glory Days, by @mercutioes (https://t.co/qtyO667FUN), which tells the story of a golden summer in the lives of a group of queer youths. It’s an absolutely charming game: nostalgic, a bit sad, gay as hell.

- (Storyteller 13) Abashed the devil stood & saw how awful goodness is, by @RookTheBird (https://t.co/3oIVE3PqAp), which deals with two enemies locked in a relationship that will kill one or both of them. It’s visceral and deals with toxicity to an extreme but it’s also gorgeous.

With the weekend upon us, remember discretion when you’re protesting. If you post pictures, blur out faces. When you write numbers on you, either have them hidden by clothing (upper arm is good) and have the number of a lawyer, not a family member or friend! Keep identities safe!

T here! I drove past a protest today of all teenagers and just wanted to remind all our listeners that young adults are changing the world every day. There are tons of youth-organized marches around the country; find one today, go march with them, and listen to what they say!

Hey Heroes! The heat wave may have broken but make sure you still have sunscreen and water when you’re protesting today. And wear a mask, of course!

If you’re not protesting but want a way to get involved, sign some petitions. Links to master threads of petitions in the replies.

We’re so proud of the work of our incredible heroes protesting, demanding change, and supporting #BlackLivesMatter around the world. If you can’t march, then sign petitions, write emails, make phone calls, donate, and educate yourselves. Keep doing the work, because it’s working.

For heroes protesting over the weekend, make sure you wear masks! They’re useful on a variety of levels, even sometimes fashionable. Bring protective eyewear and water if you can. Look for nearby spots for medical care and rest; many theatre lobbies are open. And go with a buddy!

can also be used for other purposes but don’t use them for cleaning eyes out. The coarseness of the towel can scratch corneas and it’s likely they absorbed some of the pepper spray or tear gas. 

As always, stay hydrated, stay alert, and go with a protest buddy. #BlackLivesMatter

Another tip for protesting in the summertime: Bring a towel (a hand towel is fine) that you can soak with water to wrap around the back of the neck of anyone who is showing signs of heat exhaustion. The coolness on their spine will help lower their body temperature.

Superhero stories are inherently political. We’re telling a story that examines young people standing up to an organization that wrongfully imprisons, uses excessive force, and deems themselves judge, jury, and executioner. We condemn these actions in game and in real life.

We haven’t spoken yet because there’s history of products and organizations capitalizing upon their “wokeness” and we didn’t want to perpetuate that. But silence in this time is a voice for the oppressor. We stand with #BlackLivesMatter and apologize for not speaking up earlier.

Thank you to all of our competitors. For those not competing, there are cameras in all four corners of the rooms, as well as strategically hidden in and around our heroes, through which you can watch their rampages. Please join me in wishing them well in their annhilation.

Finally, we close out with Pumpking, a mass of vines, ivy, mistletoe, and poisonous thorns, who breaks pillars and holds ships together, destroying against Miraculous, a magic-based hero who, though learning to control his powers, makes up for his control in enthusiasm,
Our penultimate fight is Daybreak, brimming with explosive light, versus Myriad, who appears when the insect hive known as Carl loses his humanity and will destroy anyone that stands against them.

In a truly tense match, we have Lady Death, a Delinquent focused on flirting and fighting with the wrong people, using illusions and a Hell-cycle, against the Night Owl, a powerful with with a lot of responsibilities.

Then, the Golden Glove, the next in a proud legacy with super strength, speed, and godlike beauty that come from his magic gloves who might bring a building down on you, competes against Coral, a hero whose acid powers can melt through anything, with nothing standing in her way.

In perhaps our hardest contest, teammates Insectivore, a.ka. Hammy, a polymorphic cosmic being tht can shatter minds with his telepathy, and Intravenous, the perfect weapon with veins of steel, go head-to-head.
In our third match of the day, Windshear, a blustery kid from the past trying to find his way in this new world, competes against the Bearoness, a literal bear with cybernetics.

Following that, The Huger, the expert hacker who loves corn dogs and can transform in size, squares off against Darren, a neon mushroom girl from beyond the stars, who loves John Hughes movies and shifting the density of her foes.
First, we have Fae, the demon-possessed woman with a tendency for turning things into shattered glass, versus Boom!, who first blew up a car and has recently moved on to the fabric of reality.

The first round, our heroes find themselves in a fancy living room and dining room. They have thirty seconds to demolish and annihilate as much as they possibly can. Which heroes will destroy more in the room? Which heroes destroy with more flair? Vote now.
